title: Developers offering $20,000 cash to high-rise apartment buyers
text:
Buyer complaints about a shortage of property in high-demand postcodes are being exacerbated by growing overseas interest in top-end houses close to major cities.

Buyers' agents such as Emma Bloom, a director of Morrell and Koren, said demand for prestigious inner-urban houses costing more than $5 million was being boosted by overseas buyers attracted by the low dollar, falling interest rates and rising prices.

But buyer fears about high-rise apartment fires and construction risks are causing sale times to blow out by more than 60 per cent compared with a year ago, creating bottlenecks for sellers, according to buyers' agents.

Lenders are also making it tougher for borrowers to buy apartments by blacklisting some postcodes, increasing deposits and lowering valuations for off-the-plan purchases.

Simon Pressley, managing director and head of market research at Propertyology, another buyers’ agency, said he expected developers to increase their commissions and incentives for high-rise apartment buyers and sellers in response to recent “poor performance combined with public concerns about cladding and other construction issues”.

Developers selling $570,000 two-bedroom, two-bathroom apartments advertise they will rent for about $575 a week, or a 5 per cent return. One-bedroom apartments with a study are selling for $450,000 and advertise $450 rent a week, also 5 per cent.

Buyers are also being offered $20,000 cash “incentives”.

Many developers are also upgrading bathroom and kitchen fixtures and offering high-end furniture.

Advertisement

Recent research found that Melbourne high-rise apartment prices are underperforming houses by more than 50 per cent in most suburbs over the past 10 years because of concerns about construction defects.

House prices grew by an average of more than 90 per cent compared with less than half of that for high rises, according to the analysis by Propertyology. In Sydney, high-rise apartments underperformed by more than 50 per cent.

But the commissions appear to be less than when the entire residential market was struggling because of low auction clearance rates, falling prices and tough lending conditions, despite low rates.

Developers were earlier this year offering advisers commissions of nearly 10 per cent, or up to $90,000 plus GST for recommending a $1 million property.
description: The payments reflect a growing division in the nation's property markets between 'hot' stock in low-rise inner suburbs and hard-to-sell high-rise and outer suburban property.
